content.description:
This is a slightly more challenging and less traveled route up Cypress Peak. 
From the basin below the North Face, look for a gully to the left to gain the ridge. 

Follow the ridge towards the summit. Before the summit is a low-5th class notch with decent exposure. This is most easily passed by descending off the ridge, passing the notch and regaining the ridge.

Descend via the NW ridge.

Approach as per the directions for the NW ridge, but at the basin below the North face, head right towards the East ridge.
Helmet, Ice Axe, Crampons

A fun, short alpine scramble with great views. Other than the slog down the FSR, most of this route is above the tree line. Car to Car, this route can easily be done in 5-6 hours with a competent party. This route has a great ridge-line scramble with one, short, easy and enjoyable crux.
Early Summer is the best time to climb, when the talus slope after the creek crossing still is covered in snow.

From the end of the FSR, follow a faint, steep trail down to Roe Creek. Cross the creek, and follow the talus/easy snow slope up to a large basin beneath the North face. Head to the right, and pick a line up to gain the NW ridge. With snow cover, you have many options and can pick a steeper & shorter route. In the summer, follow the talus to the right of the small glacier, passing around it and up to the ridge.

Once on the ridge, head towards the summit. There is a 60ft crux with massive holds/ledges and minimal exposure.

From the creek, follow the talus/easy snow slope up and to the right to gain the NW ridge.
Helmet. If there's snow, Ice Axe & Crampons.

A local classic in the Sea to Sky corridor with lots of accessible, alpine scrambles easily done in a day trip from Vancouver.

The NE Ridge is covered in Matt Gunn's book on page 72.
